headSection.headingText: The century ride. That grand, mythical beast of the cycling world, where pedal meets pavement for a grueling 100 kilometers (or 100 miles if you’re from a land where kilometers fear to tread). Whether it’s on winding roads in metric countries or sprawling miles in imperial lands, it’s a right of passage, an ode to endurance. Organized by cycling clubs, these events draw us in with the promise of camaraderie, self-doubt, and probably the finest post-ride snacks you’ll ever encounter. Some clubs even make it an annual affair - a social gathering, a fundraiser, a chance to test one’s mettle against the clock, the road, and their own excuses.
headSection.headingSubText: The origins of the century ride are as murky as a foggy mountain pass, though whispers suggest it first surfaced in the United States, circa 1890. That was when cycling was the latest craze - before smartphones, selfies, and riding for “the ‘Gram.” Back then, the goal wasn’t just to cover a distance, but to prove something: you had the endurance, the fitness, and maybe just enough madness to ride for hours on end. Fast forward to today, and the century ride remains a milestone for cyclists around the world. It’s more than just a badge of honor - it’s a love letter to the open road, a connection to the rich, sometimes bizarre history of the sport. And trust me, it’s one heck of a story to tell at the next gathering over coffee… or, you know, sports drinks.

sections.heading: October 21, 2024 – From Lviv to Zhovkva: A Ride Through Serenity, Cake, and Canine Wisdom

children.value: Yesterday, I decided to embark on a solo cycling adventure from Lviv to the picturesque town of Zhovkva and back. Let me just say, it was a ride straight out of a fairy tale. The weather? Perfect. No wind, hardly any cars, and the bike felt like it was flying. Honestly, it was one of those rides where everything aligns… except for my overthinking brain, which stubbornly insisted on revisiting work worries instead of just enjoying the moment.

Initially, I planned to stick to my “zone 2” training (for the non-cyclists: a chill pace). But, of course, that plan went out the window, as it usually does. Lesson learned: I should really stop obsessing over the numbers on my cycling computer.

When I arrived in Zhovkva, I rewarded myself with a coffee and a tiny piece of Napoleon cake at a cozy "Коц Coffee" on the main square. They served the cake with some kind of sauce that was absolutely divine. I sat outside, soaking up the sun, eavesdropping on the locals’ cheerful conversations, and enjoying the warmth. Even better, a friendly dog strolled over, and after a short “chat,” decided to sit and chill beside me. A true gentleman of the canine world.

On the way back, things got a bit tougher, but the magic never faded. One of the highlights was a quiet, enchanting forest near Ivano-Frankove. The rolling hills there were a dream to ride through. As for the workout itself, I noticed I’ve improved at keeping a steady power output on climbs. All those short ascents in the 300–400-watt range felt surprisingly smooth. Progress feels good, even if it’s a bit nerdy to measure rides in watts.
All in all, this was one of those rides that reminds you why cycling is so special. Just me, my bike, the open road… and the occasional existential crisis.

sections.heading: August 25, 2023 – Bukovel, My First Century Ride

children.value: Ah, my first 100 kilometers. I still remember the night before - staring at the ceiling, second-guessing my life choices, and plotting a route that felt ambitious, even for the freshly motivated version of me. I’d trained consistently for months, but there’s always that little voice that wonders, “Can I really do this?” Especially when the Carpathian Mountains are involved. The hills! And, well, gravity wasn’t exactly my best friend.

The ride began with a chill in the air - one of those mornings where you question why anyone would voluntarily leave a warm bed for a cold saddle. But as the sun kissed the mountains, the beauty of the Carpathians stole the show, and all my pre-ride worries melted away. Cold? What cold? I mean, except for the moments when I could only think about the cold. I stayed in HVOYA apart-hotel in Bukovel, plan was to ride from Bukovel west exit -> Bilyn -> Yablunytsia -> Tatariv -> and back to Bukovel but entering from the east. It sounded simple enough. In reality? Well, let’s just say every hill had a sense of humor I wasn’t quite ready for.

value: Distance: 100.01 km (because 100 km exactly is too mainstream)
Time total: 4h 30m (because we all need breaks, right?)
Breaks: 1 - hot dog in Yasinia (55km), 2- coffe break in Tatariv (85k)
